It is plastic and must be carried at all times. |} ===Countries with non-compulsory identity cards=== These are countries where official authorities issue identity cards to those who request them, but where it is not illegal to be without an official identity document. For some services, identification is needed, but documents such as passports or identity cards issued by banks or driving licences can be used. In countries where national identity cards are fully voluntary, they are often not so commonly used, because many already have a passport and a driving licence, so a third identity document is often considered superfluous. {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Country ! Description |- | {{flagcountry|Armenia}} || Optional{{cite web | url=http://www.identity-cards.net/record/armenia | title=Armenia | Identity-Cards.net}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Austria}} || [[Austrian identity card]] |- | {{flagcountry|Barbados}} || Optional, although compulsory for voting and other government transactions{{cite web | url=https://www.gov.bb/citizens-citi/how-do-i/national-registration-number/ | title=GOV.BB}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Belize}} || Called the "Identification Card R.R". Optional, although compulsory for voting and other government transactions. Availiable also for any Commonwealth country citizen who have lived in Belize for a year without leaving and been at least 2 months in an area where the person has been registered in.{{cite web | url=https://tacogirl.com/getting-new-belize-id-card-closing-accounts/ | title=Getting a New Belize ID Card and Closing Accounts| date=2014-08-07}}https://abelizehomeforus.files.wordpress.com/2015/03/img_8855.jpghttps://abelizehomeforus.files.wordpress.com/2014/12/img_8856.jpg. |- | {{flagcountry|Dominica}} | The Dominica national multpurpose identitification card is optional for all Dominiquais nationals and is valid for international travel within OECS countries. |- | {{flagcountry|Finland}} || A national [[Finnish identity card|identity card]] exists, usable all over the EU and a number of other countries, but commonly people use their driving licences or national [[social security]] cards as ID. |- | {{flagcountry|France}} || {{Main|French national identity card}} The country has had a national ID card since 1940, when it helped the [[Vichy France|Vichy]] authorities identify 76,000 for deportation as part of [[the Holocaust]]. In the past, identity cards were compulsory, had to be updated each year in case of change of residence and were valid for 10 years, and their renewal required paying a fee. In addition to the face photograph, the card included the family name, first names, date and place of birth, and a unique national identity number relating to the national [[INSEE]] registry, which is also used as the [[national service]] registration number, and as the [[Social Security in France|Social Security]] account number for health and retirement benefits. Later,{{When|date=July 2011}} the laws were changed{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} so that any official and certified document (even if expired and possibly unusable abroad) with a photograph and a name on it, issued by a public administration or enterprise (such as a rail transport card, student card, [[driving licence]] or [[passport]]) could be used as proof of identity.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} Also, law enforcement (''gendarmerie'') can now accept photocopies of these documents{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} when performing identity checks, provided that the original document is presented within two weeks.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} For financial transactions, any of these documents must be equally accepted as proof of identity.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} Identity cards are still issued, but are free of charge, and not compulsory. Legislation has been published for a proposed compulsory biometric card system, which has been widely criticised, among others by the "National commission for computing and liberties" (''Commission nationale de l’informatique et des libertés'', [[CNIL]]), the national authority and regulator on computing systems and databases. Identity cards issued since 2004 include basic biometric information (a digitized fingerprint record, a printed digital photograph and a scanned signature) and various anti-fraud systems embedded within the laminated card. The [[Health care in France#Health insurance|French health insurance]] card, a [[smart card]] named "[[:fr:Carte Vitale|Carte Vitale 2]]", includes a digital photograph and other personal medical information in addition to identity elements. The previous version included a chip and a magnetic stripe, but contained very little information. |- | {{flagcountry|Fiji}} || In 2010 and 2012, {{cite news|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/radio/onairhighlights/fiji-id-card-idea-being-examined |publisher=ABC Radio Australia |title=Fiji ID card idea being examined |date=15 Feb 2012}} there were proposals for a compulsory identity card ideas that did not progress. However, national voter's ID card (electronic since 2017) are available upon request and compulsory for certain governmental transactions (e.g: voting){{cite web | url=http://fijivillage.com/news/Fijian-Elections-Office-unveils-new-Voter-Card-20--r92k5s/ | title=Fijian Elections Office unveils new Voter Card 2.0}}http://fijielects2018.org.fj/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/election_information_booklet_main.pdf. |- | {{flagcountry|Gibraltar}}{{flagcountry|UK}} || {{Main|Gibraltar identity card}} The British Overseas Territory of Gibraltar has a voluntary ID card system for citizens, valid in the UK and EU member countries. |- | {{flagcountry|Iceland}} || The National Register of Persons (''Þjóðskrá'') issues national identity cards (''Nafnskírteini'') to citizens aged 14 or over. They do not state citizenship and are not usable outside the [[Nordic passport union]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.skra.is/einstaklingar/vegabref-og-skilriki/nafnskirteini/ |title=Nafnskírteini |publisher=Þjóðskrár Íslands |accessdate=10 Dec 2017}} People in Iceland are required to present identification if asked by police,{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} but driving licenses and various other ID cards are acceptable as well as the identity card. |- | {{flagcountry|Ireland}}|| {{Main|Irish passport card}} The [[Irish passport#Passport Card|Irish Passport Card]] is usable for a national identification and travel within most of Europe (including countries like Georgia and Moldova). Most people prefer the more traditional documents{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}, the driver's license since it is needed for driving, and the passport for travel. A Public Services Card was introduced in recent years to access public services. |- | {{flagcountry|Italy}} || ''[[:it:Carta d'identità italiana|Carta d'Identità]]'' (Italian Wikipedia) may be issued to anyone resident in Italy and to Italian citizens living abroad. A card issued to an Italian citizen is accepted in lieu of a passport in all Europe (except in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine) and in Turkey, Georgia, Egypt, Tunisia and Morocco. It is not compulsory to have it or to carry it, unless expressly ordered by public security authorities. The latest version is the [[Italian electronic identity card]], but the main problem is that most municipalities in Italy still issue old form of ID without machine readable zones, which often cause delays at border controls. |- | {{flagcountry|Jamaica}} || Optional, although compulsory for voting and other government transactions{{cite web | url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/lead-stories/20170908/no-id-no-access-jcans-will-need-national-identification-card-access | title=No ID, no access - J'cans will need National Identification card to access gov't goods, services| date=2017-09-08}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Liechtenstein}} || {{Main|Liechtenstein identity card}} The Principality of Liechtenstein has a voluntary ID card system for citizens, the ''Identitätskarte''. |- | {{flagcountry|Lithuania}} | [[Lithuanian identity card|''Asmens tapatybės kortelė'']] (Identity card). Passport or Identity card is compulsory at age 16. |- | {{flagcountry|Mexico}} || The National Electorate Institute (''Instituto Nacional Electoral'', INE) issues Voting cards (''credencial para votar'') to Mexican citizens over 18 years of age. This card is required to participate in Federal level elections and while it is the de facto ID for most legal transactions, it is not mandatory to have one. Mexican minors, between the ages of 4 and 17, were able to get a personal ID card named ''cédula de identidad personal'', but the government stopped issuing it in 2013. Both documents can be used to demonstrate Mexican nationality and thus enter Mexico from abroad, be it by air, sea or land. |- | {{flagcountry|Micronesia}} || National Identity cards, called “FSM Voters National Identity card”, are issued on a optional base, free of charge. The Identity Cards were introduced in 2005.{{cite web | url=http://fsmned.fm/fsmvid.html | title=History of FSMVID}} |- | {{flagcountry|Saint Kitts and Nevis}} | National Identity Card are optional. Issued since 2010{{cite web | url=http://nevisblog.com/collection-of-st-kitts-nevis-national-id-cards.html | title=Collection of St. Kitts – Nevis National ID Cards}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Saint Lucia}} | Passport or Identity card is compulsory for all Saint Lucian citizens. |- | {{flagcountry|Solomon Islands}} | "National Voter's Identity card" are optional upon request{{cite web | url=https://www.fijitimes.com/solomon-islands-electoral-commission-issues-strong-warning-on-id-card-buying-selling/ | title=Solomon Islands Electoral Commission issues strong warning on ID card buying, selling}}{{cite web | url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/367264/solomons-electoral-office-stops-issuing-voter-id-cards-over-corruption-concerns | title=Solomons electoral office stops issuing voter ID cards over corruption concerns| date=2018-09-25}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Sweden}} || {{Main|National identity card (Sweden)}} Having an identity card in Sweden is not mandatory, but it is needed in several situations, e.g. for bank services or when picking up a package at a post office.
Sweden has since 2005 issued [[Swedish national identity card|national identity cards]], but they are not compulsory and only obtainable by [[Swedish citizen]]s,{{cite web |url=http://www.polisen.se/inter/nodeid=33378&pageversion=1.jsp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630231031/http://www.polisen.se/inter/nodeid%3D33378%26pageversion%3D1.jsp |title=Fakta om nationellt id-kort |publisher=[[Swedish Police Authority]] |archivedate=30 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} mostly intended to use for intra-Schengen area travel. The Swedish tax authority does since 2009 issue official identity cards for anyone resident in Sweden. [[Driver's license]]s is the most commonly used identity document in Sweden. Between 2005 and 2009 it was almost impossible for immigrants to get a card because of tightened security to get a bank card, since a close family member having a Swedish identity document had to vouch the identity. Not having an ID card in combination with a crime giving a fine (e.g. riding public transport without a ticket), is a suspicion to escape it, which is a reason for detainment in Sweden. |- | {{flagcountry|Switzerland}} || The [[Swiss identity card]] is issued to any citizen. It is not mandatory to carry, but it or a passport is needed in some situations. Driver's licenses are not always valid as identity document as they don't expire and can be old. |- | {{flagcountry|Tanzania}} || Optional, although compulsory certain civil (SIM cards) and government transactions{{cite web | url=http://www.fema.co.tz/2018/03/without-nationa-identification-card-it.html | title=Without Nationa identification card It will be difficult to own a phone "according to NIDA"}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Togo}} || Optional to all Togolese nationals{{cite web | url=http://www.dgdn-togo.tg/page/document/identity | title=DGDN -TOGO | Carte d'Identite - TOGO}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Tonga}} || Tonga's National ID Card was first issued in 2010, and it is optional, along with the driver's licenses and passports. Either one of these are mandatory for to vote though. Applicants need to be 14 years of age or older to apply for a National ID Card.{{cite web|url=http://www.mic.gov.to/palace-office/2307-application-for-a-national-id-card-to-resume-28-march |publisher=Ministry of Information and Communications, Government of Tonga |title=Applications for a National ID Card to resume 28 March |date=25 Mar 2011 |accessdate=10 Dec 2017}} |- | {{flagcountry|Trinidad and Tobago}} || The [[Elections and Boundaries Commission]] (EBC) is responsible for the issuing of National Identification Cards. A National Identification (ID) Card is issued to a citizen or eligible resident when they register to vote. The National ID Card is an electoral document used as proof of identity when voting. It is also accepted as a primary form of identification within Trinidad and Tobago, and can be obtained before voting age. Eligible for the card are citizens of [[Trinidad and Tobago]] of 15 years of age or older, and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] citizens 15 years of age or older who have resided legally in [[Trinidad and Tobago]] for at least one year immediately preceding the application. The National ID Card is valid for 10 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.tt/gortt/portal/ttconnect/Non-ResidentDetail/?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=%2Fgortt%2Fwcm%2Fconnect%2FGorTT%20Web%20Content%2Fttconnect%2Fcitizen%2Ftopic%2Fgovernmentandpolitics%2Fdocuments+and+policies%2Fobtaining+a+national+identification+card |title=Obtaining a national identification card |publisher=Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago |archivedate=2012-08-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805054702/http://www.gov.tt/gortt/portal/ttconnect/Non-ResidentDetail/?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/gortt/wcm/connect/GorTT%20Web%20Content/ttconnect/citizen/topic/governmentandpolitics/documents+and+policies/obtaining+a+national+identification+card |df= }} It is not, however, mandatory when voting; other forms if ID, including [[passport]] or [[driver's permit]], can be presented. |- | {{flagcountry|United States}} || {{Main|United States Passport Card}} The [[Passport card|U.S. passport card]] is the '''''de jure''''' national identity card of the United States of America. The passport card is issued by the federal government via the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] upon voluntary request. The primary purpose of the passport card is used as a Federal issued Identity card and a limited [[travel document]] under the [[Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative]], similar to the usage of national identity cards in the [[Schengen Area]]. However, passport cards are also conclusive proof of U.S. citizenship under federal law, accepted for domestic airline travel under the [[REAL ID Act]],{{cite web|url=http://www.tsa.gov/travelers/airtravel/acceptable_documents.shtm |title=Acceptable IDs |publisher=Transportation Security Administration |date=13 Feb 2015 |accessdate=15 May 2015}} a List A document for [[I-9 (form)|Form I-9]] purposes,{{cite web|url=http://www.uscis.gov/portal/site/uscis/menuitem.5af9bb95919f35e66f614176543f6d1a/?vgnextoid=8daff5a7ebd9b110VgnVCM1000004718190aRCRD&vgnextchannel=55b2aca797e63110VgnVCM1000004718190aRCRD |title=USCIS Informs The Public That New Passport Card Is Acceptable For Employment Eligibility Verification |publisher=U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services |date=8 Aug 2008 |accessdate=15 May 2015}} and generally proof of identity/citizenship both inside and outside the United States.{{cite web |url=http://germany.usembassy.gov/acs/passportcard.html |title=U.S. Citizen Services in Germany: Passports and Reports at Birth |publisher=U.S. Diplomatic Mission to Germany |archivedate=27 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527100851/http://germany.usembassy.gov/acs/passportcard.html |df= }} Despite this, the predominant and de facto method of identification remains the driver's license (or non-driver ID card) issued by each state, because driver's license is needed for driving, although these generally do not indicate citizenship or nationality. In the past, compulsory ID cards or something compulsory resembling ID cards have existed, such as internal passports for freed African Americans before the [[Abolition of slavery in the USA|abolition of slavery]], and the draft cards for men (during times when men were conscripted into the army). In some states, there is a [[Stop and identify statutes|Stop and identify statute]] meaning that an identity card (or driver's license or other photo id) can be demanded. There is, however, no obligation to carry or own an identification card. |- | {{flagcountry|Vanuatu}} || National Identity Cards are being issued since October 2017. Plans for rolling out biometric cards are due for the late 2018{{cite web | url=http://dailypost.vu/news/national-id-cards-issued/article_824b994e-54b4-528b-a213-81904507e8f1.html | title=National Id Cards Issued}}{{cite web | url=http://dailypost.vu/news/vila-citizens-to-use-national-id-card-during-municipal-election/article_6a61ee2f-2a85-5983-842a-8d208d2cac56.html | title=Vila citizens to use national ID card during Municipal election early next year}}. |} ===Countries with no identity cards=== These are countries where official authorities do not issue any identity cards. When identification is needed, e.g. passports, identity cards issued by banks etc., or cards that are not mainly identity cards like driver's licenses can be used. Most countries that are not listed at all in this page have no National ID Card. {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Country ! Description |- | {{flagcountry|Andorra}} || No national identity card in the principality. Passports and driving licenses are most commonly used for identification.[https://www.diariandorra.ad/noticies/opinio/2017/06/07/cal_dni_andorra_117006_1129.html Cal un DNI andorrà] (7 June 2017) When visiting Spain a passport is needed in lack of national identity card, although driving licenses are often used and accepted unofficially. |- | {{flagcountry|Australia}} || In 1985, there was a failed proposal to create an [[Australia Card]]. In 2006 the Australian Government announced the introduction of a non-compulsory [[Health and social services access card (Australia)|Access Card]] that would act as a gateway to services administered by The Department of Human Services. This project, however, was terminated in November 2007. Class A identification documents in most Australian states include State government, Australian Passport (issued by the Federal government), foreign passport, or Residency/Citizenship documents (issued by the Federal government). |- |{{flagcountry|Bahamas}} || No national identity card. Plans for introducing new identity cards were established in 2013, however no progress has been made so far{{cite web | url=http://m.tribune242.com/news/2013/dec/24/national-id-card-being-considered-government/?templates=mobile | title=NATIONAL ID CARD BEING CONSIDERED BY GOVERNMENT | the Tribune}}. |- |{{flagcountry|Canada}} |In the past, [[Canadian nationality law#Citizenship ceremonies|Canadian citizenship cards]] were issued to new Canadians upon naturalization and established Canadians (upon request). As of 2012 these cards have been discontinued, and there is no national identity card or equivalent. Driver's licenses issued by the provinces are the primary form of identification. All provinces and territories except Quebec also issue separate photo identification cards for non-drivers. [[Health care in Canada|Health cards]] (issued by the provinces) and [[Canadian passport|passports]] (issued by the Canadian federal government) are used as supplemental or alternative identification. |- | {{flagcountry|Denmark}} || No national identity card. When needed, e.g. in banks, a passport or driver's license is used or, for age checks, a municipal identity card. Against authorities a health insurance card (without photo) can be used. |- | {{flagcountry|Japan}} || There is an optional {{nihongo|[[Basic Resident Registers Network|Juki Net]]|住基ネット|Jūki netto}} card for Japanese citizens, corresponding to the compulsory {{nihongo|[[Jūminhyō]]|住民票}} record of residential address. The compulsory {{nihongo|[[Alien registration in Japan|Certificate of Alien Registration]]|外国人登録証明書|Gaikokujin Tōroku Shōmeisho}} that all resident foreigners were required to have is being replaced with a [[Alien registration in Japan#Foreign residents' registration system|resident's ID card]] that is essentially the same as the Juki Net card, and resident foreigners are now registered in Jūminhyō, together with Japanese family (if any). Foreigners who enter the country on a visa that is valid for 3 months or less need only a passport with a valid landing permit. Driving licenses, {{nihongo|National Health Insurance Cards|国民健康保険証|Kokumin Kenkō Hoken Shō}}, Certificates of Alien Registration (or the new resident's ID card that replaces it) and passports containing a registration for a Certificate for Alien Registration are accepted as IDs for most purposes. Health insurance cards do not have a photograph of their owner. |- |{{flagcountry|Kiribati}} || No National Identity card, however the I-Kiribati government is planning to introduce national ID cards in the near future. |- | {{flagcountry|Marshall Islands}} || No national identity card in the Republic of the Marshall Islands. |- | {{flagcountry|Nauru}} || No National identity card. |- | {{flagcountry|New Zealand}} || No national identity card. Acceptable types of identification for proof of identification may include passports, firearms licences, driving licences, 18+ cards (issued by Hospitality NZ), a [[Winston Peters#SuperGold Card|SuperGold]] (senior citizen's) card, birth certificates or a citizenship certificate. |- | {{flagcountry|Norway}} || No national identity card, but private identity cards exist which are needed in banks if not using a passport or driving licence. Bank issued debit cards have had a photo of the holder on the back since the 1980s. The banks have stated that they no longer intend to issue photos on their debit and credit cards, as they think ID-cards should be a public service. This requires people who do not have a driving licence to bring their passport in many situations. Norway decided in 2007 to introduce a voluntary national identity card, to be usable for travel to EEA countries, but they are delayed{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/livsstil/etterlyser-nasjonale-id-kort-1.10910502 |title=Etterlyser nasjonale ID-kort - NRK - Livsstil |date=15 Feb 2013 |publisher=Nrk.no |accessdate=15 May 2015}} and are planned to be introduced in 2019.{{Cite news|url=http://www.abcnyheter.no/reise/2017/01/05/195268233/politiet-nye-pass-og-nasjonale-id-kort-kommer-1.-april-2018 |title=Politiet: Nye pass og nasjonale ID-kort kommer 1. april 2018 |publisher=ABC Nyheter |date=5 Jan 2017 |accessdate=9 Jan 2017}}[https://www.nrk.no/norge/tidspunkt-for-nye-pass-og-id-kort-er-helt-i-det-bla-1.14038161 Ingen tør love når nye pass og ID-kort kommer] The reason for the delay is that the responsible authority requires absolute security on both the cards and the validation of the identity at issuance. |- |{{flagcountry|Palau}} || No National Identity card. |- |{{flagcountry|Samoa}} || No National Identity card, however the Samoan government is planning to introduce national ID cards in the near future{{cite web | url=http://www.samoaobserver.ws/en/21_07_2017/local/22423/National-ID-in-the-pipeline.htm | title=National ID in the pipeline}}. |- |{{flagcountry|Turkmenistan}} || No National identity card{{cite web | url=https://www.worldprivacyforum.org/2017/07/national-ids-around-the-world/ | title=National IDs Around the World — Interactive map | World Privacy Forum}}. |- | {{flagcountry|Tuvalu}} || No National identity card. |- | {{flagcountry|United Kingdom}} || Compulsory identity cards were to be introduced under the [[Identity Cards Act 2006]]. Initial cards, not yet compulsory, were introduced for those who wanted them in 2009, but the requirement and the cards were abolished by the [[Identity Documents Act 2010]] without compensation to those who had paid for them after a change of government.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/7757720/ID-card-scheme-will-be-scrapped-with-no-refund-to-holders.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Andrew |last1=Porter |first2=James |last2=Kirkup |title=ID card scheme will be scrapped with no refund to holders |date=24 May 2010}} When a formal identity document is needed, a passport or a driving licence is needed. For those who do not have—or wish to carry—a passport or driving licence, the UK Government has instituted the [[Proof of Age Standards Scheme|PASS scheme]], which allows private companies to issue proof of age cards to UK residents, primarily for young people to prove age in the purchase of age-restricted goods and services. |- |{{flagcountry|Uzbekistan}} || No National Identity card, however the Uzbek government is planning to introduce national ID cards in the near future (counted from 2018){{cite web|url=http://tashkenttimes.uz/national/1915-national-id-cards-may-be-introduced-in-uzbekistan |title=National ID cards may be introduced in Uzbekistan |date=2018-01-10}}. |- |} ==See also== * [[Identity document]] * [[National identity cards in the European Union]] * [[Stop and identify statutes]] * [[Obligation of identification]] ==Notes== * As noted above, certain countries do not have national ID cards, but have other official documents that play the same role in practice (e.g. driver's license for the United States). While a country may not make it ''[[de jure]]'' compulsory to own or carry an identity document, it may be ''[[de facto]]'' strongly recommended to do so in order to facilitate certain procedures. * In most countries, non-resident foreign citizens have to be able to identify themselves through a passport. For residents with "foreign" characteristics (e.g. skin color, dialect) possession of an acceptable identity card might be useful to reduce the risk of harassment from the police and other authorities. * In many countries, people suspected of crime will be detained until their identity is proven even in countries not requiring an identity card. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Identity cards}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Identity Card Policies}} [[Category:Identity documents]] [[Category:Society-related lists]] [[Category:Lists by country]] [[Category:National identity cards|*]]

page.title: List of urban centers in Istanbul

revision.comment: /* Related lists */ a non-link to the article readers are currently looking at is pointless
revision.text:
The '''list of urban centers''' in [[Istanbul]] lists the relevant civic centers (markets, neighborhoods and places) within the city limits of Istanbul.
{{col-begin}}{{col-break|width=50%}} *[[Anadoluhisarı]] *[[Arnavutköy]] *[[Ataşehir]] *[[Bakırköy]] *[[Bebek, Istanbul|Bebek]] *[[Beşiktaş]] *[[Beylerbeyi Palace|Beylerbeyi]] *[[Beyoğlu]] *[[Bosphorus]] *[[Çengelköy]] *[[Cihangir]] *[[Eminönü]] *[[Emirgan]] *[[Eyüp]] *[[Fatih]] *[[Galata]] *[[Golden Horn]] *[[The Grand Bazaar, Istanbul|The Grand Bazaar]] *[[İstiklal Avenue]] *[[Kadıköy]] *[[Kandilli, Istanbul|Kandilli]] *[[Kanlıca]] *[[Karaköy]] *[[Maltepe, Istanbul|Maltepe]] *[[Nişantaşı]] *[[Ortaköy]] *[[Princes' Islands]] *[[Rumelihisarı]] *[[Sarıyer]] *[[The Spice Bazaar, Istanbul|The Spice Bazaar]] *[[Taksim Square]] *[[Tarabya]] *[[Üsküdar]] *[[Yedikule]] *[[Yeniköy, Istanbul|Yeniköy]] *[[Yeşilköy]] The cross-continent [[European walking route E8]] trail begins/ends here, running {{convert|4700|km|0|abbr=on}} to [[Cork (city)|Cork]], [[Ireland]]. {{col-break|width=50%}} File:IstanbulAtNight.jpg|The densest metropolitan area is seen more clearly at night. File:DolmabahceMainGate.JPG|[[Dolmabahçe Palace]] File:Aya sofya.jpg|[[Hagia Sophia|Hagia Sophia Museum]] File:Twierdza Rumeli Istambuł RB1.jpg|[[Rumeli Hisarı]] File:Istanbul - Basilica Cistern - 01.JPG|[[Basilica Cistern]] File:Pałac Küçüksu Istambuł RB1.jpg|[[Küçüksu Summer Palace]] File:EgyptianObelisk.jpg|Obelisk of [[Thutmosis III]] at the [[Hippodrome of Constantinople]] File:Ortaköy.jpg|[[Ortaköy Mosque]] and the [[Bosphorus Bridge]] File:Resim12 026.jpg|[[Kızkulesi, Istanbul|Kız Kulesi (Maiden's Tower)]] is sometimes considered the symbol of Istanbul. File:Istiklal daytime.jpg|[[İstiklal Avenue]] File:Cevahir Shopping Mall in Istanbul.jpg|[[Cevahir Mall]] File:istanbulmetros.jpg|[[Istanbul Metro]] File:Kanyon Shopping Mall, Istanbul - day shot.jpg|Among İstanbul's many malls [[Kanyon (Istanbul)|Kanyon]] captures the attention through its outstanding architecture. File:Genealogy of Jesus mosaic at Chora (1).jpg|[[Chora Church]] (Kariye Müzesi) File:Buildings in Cihangir Biyoglu Istanbul.jpg|[[Arnavutköy]] on the [[Bosporus]] File:Taksim square - Istanbul, 2014.10.24 (24).JPG|Taksim Square {{col-end}}
==Related lists== *[[List of museums and monuments in Istanbul]] *[[List of universities in Istanbul]] *[[List of schools in Istanbul]] *[[List of architectural structures in Istanbul]] *[[List of columns and towers in Istanbul]] *[[List of libraries in Istanbul]] *[[List of mayors of Istanbul]] *[[List of Istanbulites]] == External links == *[http://wheretogoinistanbul.blogspot.com/ Where to go in Istanbul] {{DEFAULTSORT:Urban Centers}} [[Category:Geography of Istanbul]] [[Category:Istanbul-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of populated places in Turkey|Istanbul]]

[[File:Independence Square in New Year 2015.JPG|thumb|250px|Independence Square in New Year 2015]] [[File:Tashkent-uzbekistan-feve.jpg|thumb]] '''Independence Square''' ({{lang-uz|Mustaqillik Maydoni}}, Мустақиллик Майдони) is a central square of [[Tashkent]], [[Uzbekistan]].<ref name="Independence Square (Mustaqillik Maydoni)">{{cite web | url=http://www.minube.net/place/independence-square-mustaqillik-maydoni--a459321 | title=Independence Square (Mustaqillik Maydoni) | publisher=Minube | accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref>
==Introduction== After the proclamation of [[Independence Day (Uzbekistan)|Uzbekistan's independence]] in September 1991, "Lenin Square" was renamed in 1992 as "Mustaqillik Maydoni", which translates to "Independence Square" in English. The monument to Lenin was dismantled, and in its place the Monument of Independence of Uzbekistan, in the form of the globe, was erected. Later, in front of the pedestal was set a figure of a woman, symbolising the [[Motherland]].<ref name="Poytaxtning bosh maydoniga “Mustaqillik maydoni” nomi berilganiga 16 yil bo‘ldi">{{cite web | url=http://uza.uz/uz/society/poytaxtning-bosh-maydoniga-mustaqillik-maydoni-nomi-berilganiga-16-yil-boldi-04.09.2007-447 | title=Poytaxtning bosh maydoniga "Mustaqillik maydoni" nomi berilganiga 16 yil bo‘ldi | publisher=Uza.Uz | date=4 September 2007 | accessdate=6 January 2015| language=Uzbek}}</ref>
Independence Square is now the central square of Tashkent; it hosts celebrations and military parades in the days of special events and public holidays.
==History== The largest square in Tashkent is more like a large park than a square. With several monuments and fountains, surrounded by impressive public buildings and filled with trees and flower beds, the Independence Square in Tashkent is a showcase of modern Uzbekistan.
Today the Independence History consists of several areas: administrative buildings, the recreation area with green zones and fountains, monuments including the Arch of Independence and the Independence Monument.
The story of the Independence square as a center of Tashkent goes back to more than hundred years. The General Governor of Turkestan erected here his military fortress in 1865. Since 1974 this place was called the Avenue of Parades, where military parades and demonstrations of workers were held to celebrate the holidays of May 1, International Workers Day, May 9 - Victory Day, November 7 - Revolution Day.
Passing through the arch of silver with figures of storks around the fountain, which marks the entrance to the Independence Square, you will see the main monument of the Independence square. It is a high pedestal with a golden globe erected on the top. Before the pedestal there is a statue of a seated mother with a baby in her arms. The monumental complex represent the revival of Uzbekistan as a free independent state. The Monument of Independence was erected in 1992, and the complete reconstruction of the area was completed in 2006.
On the opposite sits a statue depicting a mourning mother sadly looking down onto an eternal flame in memory of her children who fell when defending the country, to commemorate the fallen unidentified soldiers in the past World Wars.
Administrative buildings, including the Cabinet of Ministers, Senate of Uzbekistan and the Ministry of Finance are located on the western side of the Independence square in Tashkent.
==Inside Independence Square== [[File:Medvedev at the Monument to the Independence of Uzbekistan.jpg|thumb|[[Dmitry Medvedev]] at the Monument to the Independence of Uzbekistan.]] * '''[[Ministry of Finance (Uzbekistan)|Ministry of Finance]]''' of Uzbekistan is almost inside of independence square and it is located left side of Independence Square. * '''[[:uz:Xotira va qadrlash maydoni|Memory Area]]''' is also inside the square but it is in the right bottom of independence square. * ''' [[Memory Lane (Uzbekistan)|Memory Lane]]''' is a place which have peoples' name who was participated in the second world war from Uzbekistan. * '''[[Arch of Ezgulik]]''' in English a word "Ezgulik" means that "Humanism" from the dictionary meaning and it means to people peacefulness. * '''[[Ankhor River]]''' is medium river which crosses Independence Square. * '''[[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (Tashkent)]]''' a monument to Soviet Soldiers in WWII. * '''[[Monument to the Independence of Uzbekistan]]''' a monument made in honor of the independence of Uzbekistan.
==Photo gallery== <center> <gallery> File:Independence square in Tashkent.jpg File:Independence square in Tashkent, Monument.jpg File:Independence square in Tashkent, Motherland figure.jpg File:Independence square enterence Tashkent.jpg </gallery> </center>

[[File:Ptolemy Cosmographia 1467 - world map.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Nicolaus Germanus's 1467 manuscript copy of [[Claudius Ptolemy|Ptolemy]]'s [[Ptolemy's world map|world map]], displaying Nicolaus Germanus's form of Ptolemy's 2nd projection and the expanded knowledge of [[Scandinavia]] in the northwest.{{sfnp|Suárez|1992}}]] [[File:Gulf4..JPG|thumb|right|400px|A 1474 printed version of Nicolaus Germanus's map]] [[File:1482 Cosmographia Germanus.JPG|thumb|right|400px|Johannes Schnitzer's [[Ptolemy's world map|world map]] from Holle's 1482 edition of [[Claudius Ptolemy|Ptolemy]]'s ''[[Ptolemy's Geography|Geography]]''.]] '''Nicolaus Germanus''' ({{circa|lk=no|1420|1490}}) was a [[Germans|German]] [[cartographer]] who published an edition of [[Jacopo d'Angelo]]'s [[Latin]] translation of [[Claudius Ptolemy|Ptolemy]]'s ''[[Ptolemy's Geography|Geography]]''. He also created two [[globe]]s depicting earth and sky in 1477, predating [[Martin Behaim]]'s ''[[Erdapfel]]''.
==Name== ''Nicolaus Germanus'' is the [[Latin]] form of the name "[[Nicholas]] the [[Germans|German]]". His exact name is unknown, although it is often given with ''Donis'', ''Donnus'', ''Donmus'', or ''Donus''. These are not, however, names but abbreviated forms of the Latin title "Lord" (''Dominus'').<ref>{{citation |contribution-url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11068a.htm |contribution=Nicolaus Germanus |title=[[Catholic Encyclopedia]] }}.</ref>
{{anchor|History|Bibliography}} ==Life== The exact dates of his birth and death are not known. He is sometimes referred to as a [[Humanism|Humanist]]{{sfnp|Suárez|1992}} [[Christian monk|monk]] of the [[Benedictine order]]{{efn|The Benedictine monk Donnus Nicholas Germanus ([[floruit|fl.]] 1460-75) was particularly prolific in editing and expanding the Geographia.<ref>[http://www.usm.maine.edu/~maps/exhibit5/sec1.html]</ref>}} possibly from [[Reichenbach Priory (Baden-Württemberg)|Reichenbach Priory]] (now in [[Baden-Württemberg]]).{{efn|Domnus Nicolaus Germanus, a Benedictine (of Reichenbach?) (1466), was the first scholar who modernized [[Ptolemy]] by means of new maps and made him generally accessible. The Benedictine [[Andreas Walsperger]] (1448) made a map of the world in the medieval style. That of the Camaldolese [[Fra Mauro]] (1457) is the most celebrated of all monuments of medieval cartography. It was already enriched by data furnished in Ptolemy's work. The map of Germany designed by Cardinal [[Nicholas of Cusa]] (1401-64), a pupil of [[Paolo dal Pozzo Toscanelli|Toscanelli]] (1387-1492), was printed in 1491. This prelate was the teacher of [[Peuerbach]] (1432-61), who in turn was the master of [[Regiomontanus]] (1436-67), the most illustrious astronomer since Ptolemy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.subjectgeo.com/wiki/Geography_and_the_Church |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008070103/http://www.subjectgeo.com/wiki/Geography_and_the_Church |archivedate=2007-10-08 |df= }}.</ref>}} His manuscript edition of Ptolemy was ready by around 1468, but not published until 1482.{{sfnp|Suárez|1992}}
==Works== In 1477, two years after the opening of the [[Vatican Library]], Nicolaus Germanus created a globe each for earth and sky, for which he was paid 200 [[ducat]]s on 11 December 1477 according to a receipt.<ref>[[:de:Bild:Germanus.jpeg]]</ref> An additional three ducats were paid the next day for the adding of the papal coat of arms, and four more on 20 December for two covers. The globes are listed in an inventory of 1481. The marchesa of [[Mantua]], Isabella, asked for copies in 1505.{{efn|{{lang-it|Intendiamo, che ne la libraria dil papa sono due spere solide: In una è depicto el Mapamundo, in l'altra li Signi Celesti, cio è el Zodiaco...}}}} The globes were kept in Salle Pontifica (Magna Secreta) until they were lost in the [[1527 Sack of Rome]]. The earth globe of Nicolaus Germanus is considered the first modern to be documented.
Nicolaus Germanus's editions of Ptolemy are notable for including four new inset maps showing new European discoveries and for modifying the world map to reflect Italians' better knowledge of [[Scandinavia]]<ref name=uminn/> following [[Claudius Clavus]]'s 1424 visit to Italy.{{sfnp|Suárez|1992}} Nicolaus Germanus was also the first Western cartographer to publish Ptolemy's more difficult second projection,{{efn|An earlier Greek cartographer completed one in manuscript for [[Maximus Planudes]] {{circa|lk=no|1300}}. It is held in Turkey.<ref>[http://www.biblioserver.com/newberry/index.php?m=word&kid=17759026 Codex Seragliensis GI 57].</ref>}} in which parallels of [[latitude]] are made equidistant but [[meridian (geography)|meridians]] converge toward the poles;{{sfnp|Suárez|1992}} it became known in his time as the "Donis Projection".
* {{citation |author=Claudius Ptolemaeius |authormask=Ptolemy |authorlink=Claudius Ptolemy |display-authors=0 |url=https://archive.org/details/cosmographia00ptol |editor-last=Germanus |editor-first=Nicolaus |publisher=Leinhart Holle |date=1482 |location=Ulm |title=Claudii Ptolomei Viri Alexandrini Cosmographie Octavus et Ultimus Liber Explicit Opus }}. {{la icon}}
It was reprinted the same year and again in 1486, with more gold. The 1486 edition is notable as the first atlas to be colored by its publisher prior to sale; uncolored editions are rare.{{sfnp|Suárez|1992}} The printing of the [[Ptolemy's world map|world maps]] in these books was credited to "Johann the Block-cutter" (''Johannes Schnitzer'') or "Johann from [[Armsheim]]" (''{{lang|la|Johannes de Armssheim}}''), distinctive for his use of a reversed capital {{angle bracket|N}} (i.e., {{angle bracket|И}}).<ref name=uminn>{{citation |contribution-url=https://www.lib.umn.edu/apps/bell/map/PTO/TOUR/1482u.html |contribution=1482: Ulm |url=https://www.lib.umn.edu/bell |title=James Ford Bell Library |publisher=University of Minnesota |location=Minneapolis |date=2001 |accessdate=7 August 2016 }}.</ref>
==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== ===Citations=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{citation |first=Józef |last=Babicz |contribution=The Celestial and Terrestrial Globes of the Vatican Library, Dating from 1477, and their Maker Donnus Nicolaus Germanus (ca 1420 – ca 1490) |title=Der Globusfreund |date=1987 |number=No. 35-37 |pp=155-168 }}. * {{citation |title=Shedding the Veil: Mapping the European Discovery of America and the New World |last=Suárez |first=Thomas |url=https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=XqjsCgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |publisher=World Scientific Publishing |location=Singapore |date=1992 |contribution-url=https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=XqjsCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT39 |contribution=6. The Known World |p=[https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=XqjsCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT39 24] }}.
==External links== {{Commons category|Donnus Nicolaus Germanus}} *[http://www.polona.pl/dlibra/doccontent2?id=61&dirids=4 ''Cosmographia Claudii Ptolomaei Alexandrini'', 1467] *http://deposit.ddb.de/online/inkunabel/boe206.htm *[http://www.stub.ch/dach/ch/ch/reviews/15_1.html Mitteleuropakarte – Germania tota tabella – von Nicolaus Cusanus in der Redaktion von Nicolaus Germanus, ca. 1478, nach ihrer Inkunabeledition, Eystat 1491.] *[http://www.phil.uni-passau.de/histhw/tutcarto/deutsch2/4-3-de.html Während der letzten Hälfte des 15. Jahrhunderts. fügt der deutsche Mönch Nicolaus Germanus die ersten modernen und korrigierten Landkarten zur Geographie des Ptolemäus hinzu.]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nicolaus Germanus, Donnus}} [[Category:German cartographers]] [[Category:Medieval German geographers]] [[Category:1420s births]] [[Category:1490s deaths]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:15th-century geographers]] [[Category:15th-century German people]] [[Category:15th-century German writers]]

'''Noorlander''' or '''de Noorlander''' is a [[Dutch language|Dutch]] [[toponymic surname]].<ref>[http://www.cbgfamilienamen.nl/nfb/detail_naam.php?gba_lcnaam=noorlander&gba_naam=Noorlander&nfd_naam=Noorlander&operator=eq&taal= Noorlander] at the [[Centraal Bureau voor Genealogie|CBG]] database of Dutch surnames.</ref> Notable people with the surname include:
*[[Ed de Noorlander]] (born 1945), Dutch decathlete *[[Seda Noorlander]] (born 1974), Dutch tennis player

page.title: Order of Wearing of honours awarded prior to 6 October 1992

revision.comment: Changed text to make factually correct (although title is still incorrect) - the 1992 date only refers to the award of Imperial honours, not all honours. That's why the "awarded after 1992" list includes commemorative medals that haven't been awarded since 1902!
revision.text:
The Order of Wearing of [[Australian Honours System|Australian honours]] includes Imperial honours (those of the British Empire/United Kingdom) if they were awarded prior to 6 October 1992. Imperial honours awarded after 5 October 1992 are considered foreign.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf "The Order of Wearing Australian Honours and Awards"], updated 25 September 2007. (Includes official post-nominals.) ''It's an Honour'' For the Order of Wearing of Australian honours ''excluding'' Imperial honours, see [[Australian Honours Order of Wearing]]. == Order of Wearing == Honours and Awards listed in '''bold''' print are: * those within the Australian System of Honours and Awards; * those conferred by The Sovereign in exercise of the [[Royal Prerogative]]; * those within the Order of St John; and * foreign awards, the acceptance and wearing of which have been authorised by the Governor-General. Honours and Awards listed in unbolded print and marked with * are Imperial awards and are considered Australian if conferred prior to 6 October 1992. If conferred after 5 October 1992, Imperial awards are foreign and should be worn accordingly.''"- all Imperial awards made to Australian citizens '''after''' 5 October 1992 are foreign awards and should be worn accordingly."'' [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf ''Order of Wearing''], updated 25 September 2007. page 1. (Generally, foreign awards are worn ''after'' Australian awards, and postnominals of foreign awards are not recognised.) # [[Image:Victoria Cross (UK) ribbon.png|90px]] [[Victoria Cross]]/'''[[Victoria Cross for Australia]]'''''"Refers to both the Imperial [[Victoria Cross]] and the [[Victoria Cross for Australia]]."'' [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/awards/docs/order_of_wearing.pdf ''Order of Wearing''], Page 5, Note 1. (Generally, foreign awards are worn ''after'' Australian awards, and postnominals of foreign awards are not recognised.) {{double image|right|Flag of France.svg|185|Armoiries république française.svg|108|The [[Flag of France]]|The [[National emblem of France]] }} [[File:LocationFrance.png|thumb|The location of [[Metropolitan France]]]] [[File:Outre-mer en sans Terre Adelie.png|thumb|The territory of the [[France|French Republic]]]] [[File:Départements+régions (France)-2016.svg|thumb|An enlargeable map of [[Metropolitan France]]]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview and topical guide of France: '''[[France]]''' – country in Western Europe with several [[Overseas departments and territories of France|overseas regions and territories]]. [[Metropolitan France]] extends from the [[Mediterranean Sea]] to the [[English Channel]] and the [[North Sea]], and from the [[Rhine]] to the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. From its shape, it is often referred to in French as ''{{lang|fr|l’Hexagone}}'' ("The [[Hexagon]]"). {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == General reference == [[File:France-Constituent-Lands.png|thumb|Constituent lands of the French Republic]] * Pronunciation: {{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-France.ogg|lang|ˈ|f|r|æ|n|s}} or {{IPAc-en|ˈ|f|r|ɑː|n|s}}, {{IPA-fr|fʁɑ̃s|lang}}; (the '''French Republic''': {{lang-fr|République française}}, {{IPA-fr|ʁepyblik fʁɑ̃sɛːz|pron}}) * Common English country name: [[France]] * Official English country name: The [[French Republic]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages|La France]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states|République française]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): French (can refer to people, language or anything related to the country) * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): [[French people|French]] (or Frenchman/Frenchwoman) * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of France]] * [[International rankings of France]] * [[ISO country codes]]: FR, FRA, 250 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:FR]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.fr]] == Geography of France == [[File:700x700 CARTE FRANCE GEO Regions R1.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Metropolitan France]]]] [[Geography of France]] * France is a: ** [[Country]] *** [[Developed country]][http://hdr.undp.org/en/media/HDR_2009_EN_Complete.pdf Overcoming barriers: Human mobility and development]. Human Development Report 2009. the United Nations Development Programme. New York. {{ISBN|978-0-230-23904-3}} ** [[Sovereign state]] *** [[Member State of the European Union]] * Location: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]], on the [[Prime Meridian]] *** [[Eurasia]] **** [[Europe]] ***** mostly in [[Western Europe]] {{efn|name=twelve|[[French Guiana]] is located in [[South America]]; [[Guadeloupe]] and [[Martinique]] are in the [[Caribbean]]; and [[Réunion]] and [[Mayotte]] are in the [[Indian Ocean]], off the coast of [[Africa]]. All five [[Administrative divisions of France#Overseas|are considered integral parts of the republic]].}} ** [[Time in France]] *** [[Time zone]]s: **** [[Metropolitan France]] – [[Central European Time]] ([[UTC+01]]), [[Central European Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) ** [[Extreme points of France]] (major towns)Map of France, SitesAtlas.com, 2009, webpage: [http://www.sitesatlas.com/Maps/Maps/507.gif SitA-507]. *** North: [[Dunkirk]] at the [[North Sea]] *** South: [[Perpignan]], at the Spanish border *** East: [[Haguenau]], at the German border *** West: [[Brest, France|Brest]], south of [[Land's End]] (England) *** High: [[Mont Blanc]] {{convert|4810|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} – highest point of [[Western Europe]] *** Low: [[Les Moëres]] {{convert|-2.5|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} ** Land boundaries: 4072 km (2529 mi) ***[[Metropolitan France]]: 2,889 km (1794 mi) {| width=510px style="margin-left:75px" | width="33%" | {{Flag|Spain}} 623 km

** [[Rail transport in France]] *** [[Trams in France]] * [[Water supply and sanitation in France]] == Education in France == [[Education in France]] The three stages of the education process in France: * [[Education in France#Primary education|Primary education]] (''enseignement primaire'') * [[Secondary education in France|Secondary education]] (''enseignement secondaire'') ** [[Secondary education in France#Collège|Collèges]] {{IPA-fr|kɔˈlɛʒ|}} - cater for the first four years of secondary education from the ages of 11 to 15 ** [[Secondary education in France#Lycée|Lycées]] ({{IPA|[liˈse]}}) - provide a three-year course of further secondary education for children between the ages of 15 and 18, during which pupils are prepared for the ''[[baccalauréat]]'' (commonly referred to as ''le bac''). * Higher education (''enseignement supérieur'') ** [[List of colleges and universities in France|Colleges and universities in France]] *** [[List of public universities in [[File:Annelinn, Anne 80 (2).JPG|thumb|300px|Panel building in [[Tartu]], [[Estonia]].]] '''Panel buildings''' may refer to [[building]]s of one of the following types:
*Built of [[structural insulated panel]]s *Built of pre-fabricated [[concrete masonry unit|concrete blocks]], named differently in various countries. *Large Panel System building, often called [[Plattenbau]] from German or [[Panelák]] from Czech and Slovak, [[Blok_mieszkalny|Blok]] from Polish or [[Panelház]] in Hungarian. Most, but not all [[Khrushchyovka]] houses in the former Soviet Union are also constructed using this technology.
Panel buildings can be either frameless ([[column]]-less), or the panels can be fitted to: * [[timber framing|Timber]]-, [[steel frame|steel]]- or [[reinforced concrete]]-[[framing (construction)|framed]] buildings, * over common blockwork, * or over existing [[masonry]] products.
== See also == *[[Prefabricated building]]

revision.text:
{{advert|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox organization | logo = Reall_Logo.jpg | type = [[Charitable organization|Registered Charity]] No. 1017255 (Scotland: SC041976) | key_people = {{plainlist| * David Orr {{small|(Chair of the Board)}} }} | footnotes = | name = Reall | founded_date = 1989 | location = [[Coventry]], [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], UK<!-- this parameter modifies "Headquarters" --> | origins = British [[Housing association]]s | area_served = [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] and [[Asia]] | product = | mission = | focus = [[Slum]]s, urban [[poverty]] | method = Supporting partner organisations; grants, financial services, technical assistance and advocacy | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 22 | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Seeing potential beyond poverty. | homepage = {{url|http://www.reall.net/}}<ref name="reall">{{cite web|title=Homeless International rebrands as social enterprise reall|url=http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/homeless-international-rebrands-social-enterprise-reall/communications/article/1312582|website=Third Sector|accessdate=30 January 2017}}</ref> | dissolved = }}
'''Reall, Real Equity for All,''' (formerly Homeless International) is a social enterprise focusing on urban [[poverty]] issues (including [[slum]]s and [[social housing]]) in the [[developing world]]. It is a registered both as a [[Charitable organization|charity]] and a [[company limited by guarantee]].
== History == Reall, previously Homeless International, was initially created in 1989, following the ''International Year of Shelter for the Homeless Trust'' or IYSH Trust UK, for the 1987 [[International Year of Shelter for the Homeless]].<ref>{{harvnb|McLeod|Mullard|2006|p=11}}</ref> The trust organised a fundraising campaign and offered grants to more than 100 projects, both in the UK and overseas, all related to shelter issues.
After the year ended, demand for support was still present in developing countries (for instance for establishing land tenure, offering loans for house improvements, improving basic infrastructure); the remaining funds were used to set up a permanent organisation, Homeless International, established in 1989. The trustees appointed Ruth McLeod as director, and she remained chief executive until 2007, when Larry English took her succession.
In 2014, Homeless International rebranded as Reall, reflecting its transition from an international development charity to a social enterprise.<ref name="reall" />
Reall's work is mainly focused on community-led initiatives and on urban poverty, although some of its current partner organisations also work in rural areas. It helps slum dwellers by supporting the development of civil society organisations in Africa and Asia that are rooted in communities and that create housing and basic services solutions, which are economically, socially and environmentally sustainable.
== Activities == Reall works by supporting community-led projects and initiatives related to [[slum upgrading]] and [[social housing]] development in over 13 countries by supporting 16 local organisations. It provides grants helping these organisations to accomplish their projects and to build their capacity; organisational development support and technical assistance for housing and infrastructure projects; bank guarantees from the Guarantee Fund; capital grants and loans from the [[Community-Led Infrastructure Finance Facility]] (CLIFF); loans from the Bond.
=== Grants === Reall disburses around £1 million of grants every year to partner organisations, especially for younger organisations which are developing community work, undertaking surveys and mapping of slums, and piloting demonstration schemes in housing and infrastructure (such as [[water supply]] and [[sanitation]]). Such grants are funded by [[Department for International Development|DFID]], [[Comic Relief]], the [[Big Lottery Fund]], the [[EuropeAid Development and Cooperation|European Commission]], the [[Jersey]] Overseas Aid Commission, and private trusts and foundations such as the Baring Foundation.<ref>Homeless International's Directors' Reports 2008-2012</ref>
=== The Guarantee Fund === The Guarantee Fund was established in 1994 to enable communities of slum dwellers to access loans from banks. Given the perceived high risk of lending to slum dwellers, few banks in developing countries are willing to lend to such organisations. The Guarantee Fund was created to offer guarantees to bank so as to lower their perceived risk. The main contributors to the Fund have been UK [[Housing Association]]s through long-term deposits. The Guarantee Fund has been used chiefly in India and Bolivia.
=== CLIFF === {{Main|Community-Led Infrastructure Finance Facility}} The Community-Led Infrastructure Finance Facility (CLIFF) was created as the result of a DFID-funded research entitled ''Bridging the Finance Gap'', started in 1999, and first piloted in 2002 in India.<ref>{{harvnb|McLeod|Mullard|2006|p=20}}</ref> It is a [[venture capital]] facility which allows communities to implement demonstration projects, in order to secure funding for larger-scale projects. CLIFF is typically used to fund more mature organisations, able to take on loans and larger amounts of [[capital finance]], but still unable to access mainstream [[housing finance]] (especially in countries where the [[financial sector]] is still under-developed).
Reall coordinates CLIFF. A first phase ran between 2002 and 2010, with almost £10 million funded by DFID and [[Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency|SIDA]]; a second phase is running until 2015, with around £20 million committed by the same funders.<ref>Homeless International, [http://www.homeless-international.org/document_1.aspx?id=0:59668&id=0:59663&id=0:59166&id=0:59153 How CLIFF works]</ref> CLIFF started in India in 2002, in Kenya in 2005, in the Philippines in 2007, in Nepal in 2010, and in West Africa, Malawi, Angola and Zimbabwe in 2011.
=== Bond === The Bond (originally named "The Africa Bond") is a [[soft loan]] facility created in 2007, funded mostly by UK Housing Associations through interest-bearing deposits, aimed at providing soft loans to local partner organisations unable to access other forms of loan finance. Loans are typically issued at 6% per annum, for housing projects. As of 2012, loans have been issued to NACHU.<ref>Homeless International,[http://www.homeless-international.org/document_1.aspx?id=0:59665&id=0:59662&id=0:59166&id=0:59153 How the Bond works]</ref>
== Partner organisations ==
=== Current partners ===
Homeless International currently supports the following local organisations.
* In [[Angola]]: [[Development Workshop]] * In [[India]]: ** [[Integrated Village Development Project|IVDP]] in [[Tamil Nadu]] ** The Indian Alliance India-wide, composed of the NGO [[Society for the Promotion of Area Resource Centers|SPARC]], the networks [[Mahila Milan]] and [[National Slum Dwellers Federation|NSDF]], and the non-profit construction company [[Nirman]]. * In [[Kenya]]: ** [[Pamoja Trust]] supporting the network ''Muungano wa Wanavijiji'' ** [[National Co-operative Housing Union|NACHU]]. * In [[Malawi]]: [[Centre for Community Organisation and Development|CCODE]] supporting the Malawi Homeless People’s Federation in Malawi. * In [[Namibia]]: [[Namibia Housing Action Group|NHAG]] supporting the Shack Dwellers Federation of Namibia (IYSH Memorial Prize 2002)<ref name="ACHR2010">[http://www.achr.net/Download%20Library/Download%20Enews/ACHR%20E-news%20July%202010.pdf ACHR E-News July 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816045904/http://www.achr.net/Download%20Library/Download%20Enews/ACHR%20E-news%20July%202010.pdf |date=2010-08-16 }}</ref> * In [[Nepal]]: [[LUMANTI]] Support Group for Shelter (IYSH Memorial Prize 2006)<ref name="ACHR2010"/> * In [[Pakistan]]: the [[Orangi Pilot Project]]. * In the [[Philippines]]: The NGO [[Philippine Action for Community-Led Shelter Initiatives|PACSII]] supporting the Homeless People’s Federation of the Philippines. * In [[Sri Lanka]]: [[Sevanatha]] (IYSH Memorial Prize 2001)<ref name="ACHR2010"/> * In [[Tanzania]]: [[Centre for Community Initiatives|CCI]] supporting the Tanzania Federation of the Urban Poor. * In [[West Africa]]: [[Water and Sanitation for Africa]] (WSA), previously known as the ''Centre Régional pour l'Eau Potable et l'Assainissement à faible coût (CREPA)'', a pan-African NGO that works in 18 African countries and is based in [[Burkina Faso]]. * In [[Zambia]]: [[People's Process on Housing and Poverty in Zambia|PPHPZ]] supporting the Zambia Homeless and Poor People’s Federation. * In [[Zimbabwe]]: ** [[Dialogue on Shelter for the Homeless in Zimbabwe Trust|Dialogue Zimbabwe]] supporting the Zimbabwe Homeless People's Federation ** [[Zimbabwe National Association of Housing Cooperatives|ZINAHCO]].
Some of the above organisations are part of global networks, including [[Slum Dwellers International]], the [[Asian Coalition for Housing Rights|ACHR]], and the [[International Co-operative Alliance]].
=== Past partners ===
In the past, support was also provided to: * In [[Argentina]]: [[Fundación Vivienda y Comunidad]] * In [[Bangladesh]]: [[Dhaka Ahsania Mission|DAM]], * In [[Bolivia]]: the [[Fundación Pro-Hábitat]] until 2006, [[Urbanizacion Ecologica Miraflores]] and [[Centro de Estudios de la Realidad Economica y Social|CERES]] * In [[Brazil]]: [[Cearah Periferia]] * In [[Cambodia]]: the [[Urban Poor Development Fund]] * In [[Chile]]: [[Taller La Viga]] * In [[Colombia]]: [[Fedevivienda]] * In [[Cuba]]: ''[[Taller Transformacion Integral]]'' and ''[[Direccion Provincia de la Vivienda]]'' * In [[Ghana]]: [[People’s Dialogue on Human Settlements Ghana|PDG]] supporting the Ghana Federation of the Urban Poor, until 2010 * In [[India]]: [[Association For Development Of Repatriates and Rural Poor|AFDORP]], [[Activists for Social Alternatives|ASA]], the [[Baroda Citizens Council]], [[Community Action for Rural Development|CARD]], [[Gramalaya]], [[Grama Suyaraj]], [[Society for Community Organisation and People's Development|SCOPE]], [[Shelter Associates]], the [[Society for Cultural Awakeness Movement]], the [[Youth Charitable Organisation]]. * In [[Jamaica]]: the [[Construction Resource and Development Centre]]. * In [[Mexico]]: [[Casa y Ciudad]], [[Union De Colonob, Inquilinob Y Bolicitanteb De La Vivienda - Veracruz|UCISV-VER]], [[Instituto De Vivienda De La Asamblea De Barrios|IVAB]]. * In [[Pakistan]]: [[Saiban (organisation)|Saiban]], the [[Urban Resource Centre]], the [[Human Development Centre]] * In [[Peru]]: [[Programa de Vivienda y desarrollo Popular|Provipo]] * In [[South Africa]]: [[People's Dialogue on Land and Shelter]] until 2005. * In [[South-East Asia]]: [[Human Settlements Foundation]] * In [[Tanzania]]: [[Peramiho Homemakers League|PEHOLE]] and [[Women's Advancement Trust|WAT]] * In [[Uganda]]: [[Busoga Youth Environment Protection Association|BYEPA]] and [[Uganda Association for Social Economic Progress|USEP]]. This does not include around 50 organisations supported by the IYSH Trust during the 1987 International Year of Shelter for the Homeless.
== Notable projects ==
Examples of projects supported by Homeless International include: * Community-managed toilets piloted and replicated by SPARC in [[Mumbai]] and other Indian cities * Technical support for the relocation of 30,000 railway dwelling families and 20,000 [[Pavement dwellers|pavement dwelling]] families to permanent housing by SPARC; including bridge finance for the construction of ''Milan Nagar'', a pilot 5-story building built by pavement dwellers. * Organising the first international slum dwellers' exchange between Mumbai and [[Bogota]] in 1990, helping to start the [[Slum Dwellers International]] movement.<ref>SDI / ACHR, [http://www.sdinet.org/media/upload/documents/face_to_face__a_dialogue_on_exchanges.pdf Face to Face, a Dialogue on Exchanges]</ref> * Support to the expansion of Federations of the Urban Poor in Southern Africa and East Africa, including the Namibia Shack Dwellers' Federation ([[World Habitat Awards|World Habitat Award]] finalist 2008).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhabitatawards.org/winners-and-finalists/project-details.cfm?lang=00&theProjectID=984C39D4-15C5-F4C0-9902EBA4C82F07C7|title=World Habitat Awards - Innovation. Sustainability. Transfer.|publisher=|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> * In Kenya, CLIFF supported notably the ''[[Camp of Fire|Kambi Moto]]'' slum upgrading project, including vertical in cremental upgrading ([[World Habitat Awards|World Habitat Award]] finalist 2009).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhabitatawards.org/winners-and-finalists/project-details.cfm?lang=00&theProjectID=18A60F52-15C5-F4C0-99C4EF674461D6A1|title=World Habitat Awards - Innovation. Sustainability. Transfer.|publisher=|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> * Support to IVDP in [[Tamil Nadu]] through grants and bank guarantees, leveraging loans for the construction of houses and toilets ([[World Habitat Awards|World Habitat Award]] finalist 2010).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhabitatawards.org/winners-and-finalists/project-details.cfm?lang=00&theProjectID=8AA8BEE9-15C5-F4C0-99B36A205CB73D81|title=World Habitat Awards - Innovation. Sustainability. Transfer.|publisher=|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> * Support to the Orangi Pilot Project's innovative housing and education programmes in [[Orangi]], [[Karachi]] ([[World Habitat Awards|World Habitat Award]] winner 2001).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhabitatawards.org/winners-and-finalists/project-details.cfm?lang=00&theProjectID=13|title=World Habitat Awards - Innovation. Sustainability. Transfer.|publisher=|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> * Support to Pro Habitat in Bolivia for the eradication of the [[Chagas disease]] ([[World Habitat Awards|World Habitat Award]] winner 2000).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhabitatawards.org/winners-and-finalists/project-details.cfm?lang=00&theProjectID=25|title=World Habitat Awards - Innovation. Sustainability. Transfer.|publisher=|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref>
== Publications ==
* {{cite book | last = McLeod | first= Ruth | last2 = Mullard | first2 = Kim | title = Bridging the Finance Gap in Housing and Infrastructure | publisher = Intermediate Technology Publications | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-1-85339-639-7 | ref = harv}} * Ian Morris, Kim Mullard and Malcolm Jack, ''The growth of "financial services" provided by Homeless International'', [[Environment & Urbanization|Environment and Urbanization]] 2007; 19; 471 * ''Homeless International'', [[Environment & Urbanization|Environment and Urbanization]] 1992; 4; 168 * [http://www.homeless-international.org/document_no_image_1.aspx?id=0:59673&id=0:61606&id=0:59670&id=0:59157 CLIFF-related publications]
